unit_title: Assessment and Review: Comprehensive Rotational Motion
subject: Physics
expanded_description: Comprehensive review and assessment of rotational motion concepts covering torque, rotational dynamics, equilibrium, kinetic energy, and their applications. Includes practice problems, concept integration, and preparation for advanced topics.
learning_objectives: Integrate concepts from all rotational motion units
Solve complex problems combining multiple rotational principles
Apply rotational dynamics to real-world scenarios

core_concept.principle: Rotational motion follows systematic analogies with translational motion: force → torque (τ = rFsinθ), mass → moment of inertia (I), acceleration → angular acceleration (α), with Newton's Second Law becoming τ_net = Iα. Energy conservation extends to include rotational kinetic energy K_rot = ½Iω².
core_concept.explanation: Mastering rotational motion requires understanding both the translational-rotational analogies and the unique aspects of rotation, particularly how mass distribution affects rotational behavior through moment of inertia.

image.caption: Rotational motion integrates kinematics, dynamics, and energy concepts

sections.introduction: Effective problem-solving in rotational motion requires recognizing which principles apply and systematically applying the rotational analogs of familiar translational concepts. This section provides a framework for approaching complex rotational problems.

image.alt: Systematic approach to rotational motion problems
image.caption: Structured problem-solving approach for rotational dynamics

key_concept.definition: The rotational problem-solving framework: (1) Identify the system and rotation axis, (2) Draw extended free-body diagrams showing force application points, (3) Apply ΣF = 0 for force balance (if needed), (4) Apply Στ = Iα for dynamics or Στ = 0 for equilibrium, (5) Use rotational kinematics if motion is involved, (6) Apply energy methods when appropriate.
key_concept.context: This systematic approach ensures all relevant physical principles are considered and applied correctly, preventing common errors in rotational problem-solving.

image.caption: Systematic steps for solving rotational motion problems

principles.statement: In torque calculations, the pivot point can be chosen anywhere. Strategic selection at points where unknown forces act eliminates those forces from torque equations, simplifying the mathematics. The physical result is independent of pivot choice.
principles.application: Choose pivot at application points of unknown forces you wish to eliminate, or at the center of mass to simplify moment of inertia calculations
principles.example: For a ladder problem, choose pivot at the bottom to eliminate the unknown friction and normal forces from the torque equation
principles.analogy: Like choosing a coordinate system in translation problems - smart choice simplifies mathematics without changing physics

image.caption: Intelligent pivot selection simplifies torque equations by eliminating unknowns

worked_examples.title: Complex Equilibrium Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A 5 kg, 3 m long ladder leans against a frictionless wall at 60° to horizontal. A 70 kg person stands 2 m up the ladder. Find all forces acting on the ladder.

step_by_step.explanation: Forces: ladder weight (245 N at center), person weight (686 N at 2 m), wall normal force (F_wall), ground normal (N_ground), ground friction (f). Choose pivot at bottom.
ΣF_x = 0: f - F_wall = 0 → f = 335 N. ΣF_y = 0: N_ground - 245 - 686 = 0 → N_ground = 931 N

worked_examples.final_answer: Wall force = 335 N (→), Ground normal = 931 N (↑), Friction = 335 N (←). Friction prevents slipping.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Static equilibrium with strategic pivot selection

image.alt: Ladder with person showing all forces
image.caption: Complete force analysis using equilibrium conditions

worked_examples.title: Rolling with Energy Methods
worked_examples.problem: A hollow cylinder (mass 4 kg, radius 0.2 m) rolls without slipping down a 5 m long incline at 30°. Find its speed at the bottom using energy methods.

step_by_step.explanation: mgh = ½mv² + ½Iω²
Hollow cylinder: I = mr²
ω = v/r
mgh = ½mv² + ½(mr²)(v/r)² = ½mv² + ½mv² = mv² → v = √(gh) = √(9.8×2.5) = 4.95 m/s

worked_examples.final_answer: The hollow cylinder reaches 4.95 m/s at the bottom. Note it accelerates slower than a solid cylinder due to larger moment of inertia.

image.caption: Energy methods efficiently solve rolling motion problems

sections.introduction: Understanding and avoiding common errors is crucial for mastering rotational motion. This section identifies frequent misconceptions and provides strategies for recognizing and correcting them.

image.caption: Identifying and correcting common rotational motion errors

key_concept.definition: Critical misconceptions in rotational motion include: confusing mass with moment of inertia, misapplying the parallel-axis theorem, incorrect torque calculations due to poor lever arm identification, forgetting that τ = Iα applies about the center of mass or fixed axis, and misapplying energy conservation in rolling problems.
key_concept.context: Recognizing these common errors helps develop robust problem-solving skills and prevents systematic mistakes in rotational dynamics applications.

image.caption: Systematic approach to identifying and correcting rotational motion errors

classifications.note: Systematic problem-solving and dimensional analysis help catch many common errors before they propagate

principles.statement: Checking dimensions and units throughout calculations provides powerful error detection. Torque has units N·m = kg·m²/s², moment of inertia has kg·m², angular acceleration has rad/s², ensuring τ = Iα is dimensionally consistent. Energy terms must all have joules (kg·m²/s²).
principles.application: Use dimensional analysis to verify equations, catch unit conversion errors, and identify physically unreasonable results
principles.example: If calculating angular acceleration yields units of 1/s² instead of rad/s², an error exists in the calculation
principles.analogy: Like spell-checking writing - dimensional analysis checks the 'grammar' of physical equations

image.caption: Dimensional consistency verification prevents many calculation errors

worked_examples.title: Error Identification in Torque Calculation
worked_examples.problem: A student calculates torque for a 20 N force applied at 30° to a 0.5 m wrench as τ = (20 N)(0.5 m) = 10 N·m. Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: The student used the full length instead of the lever arm (perpendicular component)
Lever arm = rsinθ = (0.5 m)sin30° = 0.25 m
τ = F × lever arm = (20 N)(0.25 m) = 5 N·m

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct torque is 5 N·m, not 10 N·m. The error was using full distance instead of perpendicular component.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Proper lever arm calculation in torque

image.caption: Torque requires the perpendicular component of distance to pivot

worked_examples.title: Moment of Inertia Application Error
worked_examples.problem: A student uses I = ½mr² (solid disk formula) for a thin ring rotating about its central axis. Calculate the error percentage.

step_by_step.explanation: Thin ring about central axis: I_correct = mr²
I_incorrect = ½mr²

step_by_step.step: Calculate error in moment of inertia
step_by_step.explanation: Error = (I_correct - I_incorrect)/I_correct = (mr² - ½mr²)/mr² = 0.5
For same torque, α = τ/I, so angular acceleration would be wrong by factor of 2

worked_examples.final_answer: 100% error in moment of inertia calculation. The ring has twice the moment of inertia of a solid disk with same mass and radius.

image.alt: Comparison of disk and ring moments of inertia
image.caption: Different shapes with same mass and radius have different moments of inertia

worked_examples.title: Atwood Machine with Massive Pulley
worked_examples.problem: An Atwood machine has masses 3 kg and 5 kg connected over a pulley (mass 2 kg, radius 0.1 m). Find the acceleration of the masses, accounting for pulley rotation.

step_by_step.explanation: Let a = linear acceleration, α = angular acceleration, T1 and T2 = tensions. Constraint: a = rα
(T2 - T1)r = Iα = (½Mr²)(a/r) = ½Mra
From pulley: T2 - T1 = ½Ma = 1a. From masses: T2 = 5g - 5a, T1 = 3g + 3a. Substitute: (5g-5a) - (3g+3a) = a → 2g - 8a = a → 2g = 9a

worked_examples.final_answer: Acceleration = 2.18 m/s². Without pulley rotation, acceleration would be (5-3)g/(5+3) = 2.45 m/s². Pulley inertia reduces acceleration.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Combined translational and rotational dynamics with constraints

image.caption: Massive pulley systems require analyzing both translation and rotation

worked_examples.title: Rolling Race with Friction
worked_examples.problem: A solid sphere and solid cylinder of same mass and radius race down an incline with friction. Initially, both slip. Determine which starts rolling without slipping first and why.

step_by_step.explanation: Both experience same acceleration initially: a = gsinθ - μ_kgcosθ
τ = f_r = Iα → α = f_r/I. Friction f = μ_kmgcosθ is same for both
Sphere: I = ⅖mr², α_sphere = (μ_kgcosθ)r/(⅖mr²) = (5μ_kgcosθ)/(2r). Cylinder: I = ½mr², α_cylinder = (μ_kgcosθ)r/(½mr²) = (2μ_kgcosθ)/r
Rolling begins when v = rω. Sphere reaches this condition faster due to larger α (5/2 vs 2 times factor)
Sphere has smaller moment of inertia, so same torque produces larger angular acceleration

worked_examples.final_answer: The sphere starts rolling without slipping first because its smaller moment of inertia allows faster rotational acceleration for the same frictional torque.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Combined dynamics of slipping and rolling transition

image.alt: Analysis of slipping to rolling transition
image.caption: Transition to rolling without slipping depends on moment of inertia

Assuming all rolling objects accelerate equally on inclines
summary: Rotational motion mastery requires understanding systematic analogies with translation: F=ma ↔ τ=Iα, with moment of inertia I representing rotational mass. Key principles include: torque as rotational force (τ = rFsinθ), rotational kinetic energy (K_rot = ½Iω²), and conditions for equilibrium (ΣF=0, Στ=0). Problem-solving strategies involve: systematic approach selection, strategic pivot choice, dimensional analysis for error checking, and using multiple methods for verification. Common errors include lever arm miscalculation and incorrect moment of inertia application. Advanced applications synthesize these concepts in complex systems involving multiple rotating components, constraints, and coupled rotational-translational motion. This foundation prepares for advanced topics including angular momentum, rotational oscillations, and three-dimensional rotation.
